ml stack designed with all of the core concepts that kubernetes has empowered

machine likely to exist in a different system maybe even in a different cloud where you'll have an on-prem cluster

then a second system that might do you might use for a data science exploration or visualization and then maybe a third
system that you use for actual training and building your models these are all really common situations and again this
is where you do start to get into the reality of multi cloud where you may already have a entirely data-driven
pipeline and back-end built as a spark cluster or Hadoop cluster or something
like that then you know your data scientist may want to explore on their laptop and then you bring it to an
accelerated training rig to do your model building and then event obviously eventually rollout and it's not just
composable from micro service to micro service it's also tends to be highly composable up and down the stack as you

fifteen different components just to lay out a single environment OS drivers

for your training rig for your cloud and any time you get into differences
between those material differences between those that's likely an opportunity for a bug and so what you
